The exciton binding energy ( E b) and bandgap of 2D perovskites are more significantly affected by dielectric and quantum confinement effects than those of 3D perovskites. 77 In general, the dielectric constant of organic layers is much smaller than that of inorganic layers. In this case, the Coulomb interaction between the electron and the hole will be stronger because of the small shielding effect. So, the exciton binding energy of 2D perovskites is almost five times as high as that of 3D analogues. 78 The bandgap ( E g) and exciton binding energy ( E b) of (quasi‐) 2D organic–inorganic halide perovskites are summarized in Table
